Events.RelatedDescription: Opened issue "Hard package deletes don't remove vulnerability data from gallery db" (#8102) at NuGet/NuGetGallery
Events.RelatedBody:
In this code:
https://github.com/NuGet/NuGetGallery/blob/master/src/NuGetGallery/Services/PackageDeleteService.cs#L321
there is no removal of related vulnerability rows.
Specifics:
* There is a potential cascading delete of rows in `VulnerablePackageVersionRangePackages` (the m:m table which connects Packages rows to `VulnerablePackageVersionRanges` rows). This needs to be confirmed, but it seems to be the case, as we don't have orphaned rows occurring here.
* If a row in `VulnerablePackageVersionRanges` no longer has any package/version rows in Packages associated with it by a row in `VulnerablePackageVersionRangePackages`, it should be removed explicitly.
* If a row in `PackageVulnerabilities` no longer has entries in `VulnerablePackageVersionRanges` with links to it, it should be deleted explicitly.
Having orphaned rows has resulted in ingress job fails (which can also be made more robust).
If a package with vulnerabilities has been hard-deleted and is reintroduced into the database, the GitHub data can be re-polled as if it were a new package.
/cc @xavierdecoster

Events.RelatedDescription: Opened pull request "Removing TLS banner" (#8101) at NuGet/NuGetGallery
Events.RelatedBody:
Addresses https://github.com/NuGet/NuGetGallery/issues/8100

This effectively reverses changes introduced by https://github.com/NuGet/NuGetGallery/pull/8012 and https://github.com/NuGet/NuGetGallery/pull/8046 dropping the `<div>` with the banner. The CSS changes are preserved for later reuse.

Events.RelatedDescription: Opened issue "Remove TLS banner" (#8100) at NuGet/NuGetGallery
Events.RelatedBody:
A month had passed since NuGet.org had TLS 1.0/1.1 support disabled. It is time to drop the banner with the announcement.
Top search results for the error you get when you try restoring packages on affected systems although not ideal do contain a fix that should help on the majority of the systems ([Google](https://www.google.com/search?q=nuget+Could+not+create+SSL%2FTLS+secure+channel), [Bing](https://www.bing.com/search?q=nuget+Could+not+create+SSL%2FTLS+secure+channel)), so people should be able to self-help.

Events.RelatedDescription: Closed issue "NuGet.Client packages depend on .NET Standard 1.x packages." (#9723) at NuGet/Home
Events.RelatedBody:
## Details about Problem

As also happened in microsoft/msbuild#5242, NuGet's NuGet .NET Standard 2.0 packages reference some libraries that were intended for .NET Standard 1.x and are no longer maintained. What is more, these libraries do not directly target .NET Standard 2.0, they greatly expand the package dependency tree. Because we no longer support .NET Standard 1.x the simplest solution is to just remove these package references.

NuGet product used (NuGet.exe | VS UI | Package Manager Console | dotnet.exe): `NuGet.Client` packages

NuGet version (x.x.x.xxx): 5.7.0-preview.3

dotnet.exe --version (if appropriate): N/A

VS version (if appropriate): N/A

OS version (i.e. win10 v1607 (14393.321)): N/A

Worked before? If so, with which NuGet version: No

## Detailed repro steps so we can see the same problem

1. Using Paket (which shows dependencies), create a `paket.dependencies` file that contains a reference to a prerelease version of a package like `NuGet.Common`.

2. `paket install`

3. The resulting `paket.lock` file has more than 100 lines for a single dependency.

## Other suggested things

### Verbose Logs

_N/A_

### Sample Project

_N/A_

Events.RelatedDescription: Closed issue "Bug in NuGet.CommandLine.Console's PrintJustified method" (#9737) at NuGet/Home
Events.RelatedBody:
The PrintJustified method in NuGet.CommandLine.Console does not account for newlines properly when wrapping. An example of this is:

Input - 
```
Logging abstractions for Microsoft.Extensions.Logging.

Commonly Used Types:
Microsoft.Extensions.Logging
Microsoft.Extensions.Logging...
```
When we call Console.PrintJustified(2, text);

Actual Output - 
```
  Logging abstractions for Microsoft.Extensions.Logging.

Commonly Used Types:
Microsoft.Extensions.Lo...
```

Expected Output -
```
  Logging abstractions for Microsoft.Extensions.Logging.

  Commonly Used Types:
  Microsoft.Extensions.Lo...
```

Events.RelatedDescription: Closed issue "Inconsistent analyzer references between legacy and SDK projects" (#9460) at NuGet/Home
Events.RelatedBody:
NuGet version (x.x.x.xxx):

```
>msbuild /version
Microsoft (R) Build Engine version 16.7.0-preview-20215-01+aa655667e for .NET Framework
Copyright (C) Microsoft Corporation. All rights reserved.

16.7.0.21501
```

## Detailed repro steps so we can see the same problem

Unzip [Repro.zip](https://github.com/NuGet/Home/files/4512818/Repro.zip) and build the solution.

Checking the binlog, the compiler receives different sets of analyzers, even though both projects have the same PackageReference:

![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/41759/79918785-f6d11800-83e1-11ea-839b-53e1fb0a7ee6.png)

![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/41759/79918793-f9337200-83e1-11ea-9ddd-2650badbe10a.png)

In legacy project the compiler receives satellite assemblies. This is unexpected.

Events.RelatedDescription: Closed issue "NuGet Pack does not encode file names with non-ASCII characters" (#9459) at NuGet/Home
Events.RelatedBody:
## Details about Problem

**NuGet product used:** nuget.exe
**NuGet version:** 4.6.0 - 5.5.1
**OS version:** Windows 10, version 1909, 18363.778
**Worked before?** yes, 4.5.3

## Summary

Starting in NuGet 4.6.0, the pack command does not encode file names containing some special characters (such as Chinese characters: `中文文件.txt`). This causes older clients and OPC readers to behave incorrectly.

## Impact

Older NuGet client versions, including any code using NuGet.Core such as NuGet.Server (https://github.com/NuGet/NuGetGallery/issues/7955), fail to open the package.

## Detailed repro steps so we can see the same problem

1. Pack a package with Chinese characters in the file name
1. Open the .nupkg in 7-Zip and look at the file name.
1. Attempt to open the package with `System.IO.Packaging`


### 4.5.3

[TestPack.4.5.3.zip](https://github.com/NuGet/Home/files/4511729/TestPack.4.5.3.zip)

![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/94054/79897212-3980f900-83be-11ea-8c43-bbd894fa3442.png)

#### Test tool output

```
/contentFiles/any/any/modules/testpack/wwwroot/????.txt
/contentFiles/any/any/modules/testpack/wwwroot/????.txt
/package/services/metadata/core-properties/ea59128cca144a82b30ef0b3de6a08a5.psmdcp
/TestPack.nuspec
/_rels/.rels
```

### 4.6.0

[TestPack.4.6.0.zip](https://github.com/NuGet/Home/files/4511730/TestPack.4.6.0.zip)

![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/94054/79897238-469de800-83be-11ea-9f39-6bf8e6438d73.png)

#### Test tool output - .NET Core

(the non-encoded files are ignored)

```
/package/services/metadata/core-properties/e22cd3c096914f2f8f346c156d8b5167.psmdcp
/TestPack.nuspec
/_rels/.rels
```

#### Test tool exception - .NET Framework

(the non-encoded files cause an exception)

```
Unhandled Exception: System.ArgumentException: Item has already been added. Key in dictionary: 'contentFiles/any/any/modules/testpack/wwwroot/????????????.txt'  Key being added: 'contentFiles/any/any/modules/testpack/wwwroot/????????????.txt'
   at System.Collections.Hashtable.Insert(Object key, Object nvalue, Boolean add)
   at System.Collections.Hashtable.Add(Object key, Object value)
   at System.Collections.Specialized.OrderedDictionary.Add(Object key, Object value)
   at MS.Internal.IO.Zip.ZipIOCentralDirectoryBlock.ParseRecord(BinaryReader reader, Int64 centralDirectoryOffset, Int32 centralDirectoryCount, Int64 expectedCentralDirectorySize)
   at MS.Internal.IO.Zip.ZipIOCentralDirectoryBlock.SeekableLoad(ZipIOBlockManager blockManager)
   at MS.Internal.IO.Zip.ZipIOBlockManager.get_CentralDirectoryBlock()
   at MS.Internal.IO.Zip.ZipArchive.GetFiles()
   at System.IO.Packaging.ZipPackage.ContentTypeHelper..ctor(ZipArchive zipArchive, IgnoredItemHelper ignoredItemHelper)
   at System.IO.Packaging.ZipPackage..ctor(Stream s, FileMode mode, FileAccess access, Boolean streaming)
   at System.IO.Packaging.Package.Open(Stream stream, FileMode packageMode, FileAccess packageAccess, Boolean streaming)
   at System.IO.Packaging.Package.Open(Stream stream)
   at ConsoleApp1.Program.Main(String[] args) in D:\trash\2020-04-21\ConsoleApp1\ConsoleApp1\Program.cs:line 20
```

### Test tool to show problem

```csharp
using System;
using System.IO;
using System.IO.Packaging;

namespace ConsoleApp1
{
    class Program
    {
        static void Main(string[] args)
        {
            // var path = @"C:\Users\jver\Downloads\TestPack.4.5.3.zip";
            var path = @"C:\Users\jver\Downloads\TestPack.4.6.0.zip";
            using (var stream = File.OpenRead(path))
            using (var package = Package.Open(stream))
            {
                foreach (var parts in package.GetParts())
                {
                    Console.WriteLine(parts.Uri);
                }
            }
        }
    }
}
```

```
XXXX@XXX:~/$ sudo mono tools/nuget/nuget.exe update -self
Checking for updates from https://www.nuget.org/api/v2/.
Currently running NuGet.exe 4.1.0.
Updating NuGet.exe to 5.4.0.
Text file busy
```
### Sample Project: N/A

Events.RelatedDescription: Closed issue "NuGet should not fail a restore if a feed is inaccessible but no * versioning is required" (#9415) at NuGet/Home
Events.RelatedBody:
## Details about Problem

- Any nuget configuration
- Nuget Version: 4.*? Really anything recent

## Detailed repro steps so we can see the same problem

1.  Create a new project (of any real kind that has a nuget package reference). A dotnet core console app works fine. The project should have not * versioning. For example, the following package ref works:
```
  <ItemGroup>
    <PackageReference Include="Microsoft.Windows.Compatibility" Version="3.1.0" />
  </ItemGroup>
```
2. Add a feed to the Nuget.config which can't be accessed.  A 404 or a 401 works fine here. For example, the following NuGet.config:
```
<?xml version="1.0" encoding="utf-8"?>
<configuration>
  <solution>
    <add key="disableSourceControlIntegration" value="true" />
  </solution>
  <packageSources>
    <clear />
    <add key="nuget.org" value="https://api.nuget.org/v3/index.json" />
    <add key="inaccessible" value="https://api.nuget.org/v10/index.json" />
  </packageSources>
  <disabledPackageSources>
    <clear />
  </disabledPackageSources>
</configuration>
```
3. Restore. The restore will fail because the inaccessible feed cannot be accessed

## Why this shouldn't fail

We do not need to fail. Because there is no * versioning in any part of the dependency graph, the restore will either find the required packages, or it will not and it and restore will fail. **Because there is no * versioning, an exhaustive search of all input feeds is not required.**

The reason why the dotnet team wants this behavior over the current behavior is that we are an open source project that primarily works in the open, but occasionally needs to do internal builds for security fixes. When doing these security fixes, internal feeds will appear in our On release day, we:
1. Publish our built packages to nuget.org
2. Push the internal commits used to build the release to the public repos and tag them. Customers use these commits to build their own versions of the repos.
3. These commits have internal feeds in their nuget.config files, but because external customers do not have access to these feeds, they cannot build the commit without altering the nuget.config file, even though all required dependencies are accessible.

We've worked around this in .NET Core by creating scripting which dynamically alters the nuget.config file prior to build, but this is clunky, only applies to automated builds, and non-obvious.

There are some other reasons not to fail:
- If we fail, it means altering or refactoring feed structures can mean that old commits become unbuildable. For instance, the .NET Core team will remove feeds containing isolated, stable packages that are created while doing final builds as those packages are moved to nuget.org. Those feeds still exist in nuget.config from old commits, but those commits will no longer build even though the packages that they need are fully accessible.

Events.RelatedDescription: Opened issue "CVE-2020-1340 - NuGet Gallery Spoofing Vulnerability" (#45) at NuGet/Announcements
Events.RelatedBody:
A spoofing vulnerability exists when the NuGet Gallery does not properly sanitize input on package metadata values. An attacker who successfully exploited the vulnerability could perform cross-site scripting attacks and run scripts in the security context of the user viewing the malicious content.

To exploit this vulnerability, an attacker with permissions to upload packages could publish specially crafted content on a gallery page.

The security update addresses the vulnerability by correcting how NuGet Gallery sanitizes input.

**MSRC Security Guidance:** [CVE-2020-1340](https://portal.msrc.microsoft.com/en-US/security-guidance/advisory/CVE-2020-1340)
**Security Update:** [v2020.06.09](https://github.com/NuGet/NuGetGallery/releases/tag/v2020.06.09)
